     203             :   static bool     IsCallerChrome();

     205             :   static bool     IsCallerContentXBL();
     206             : 
     207             :   // The APIs for checking whether the caller is system (in the sense of system
     208             :   // principal) should only be used when the JSContext is known to accurately
     209             :   // represent the caller.  In practice, that means you should only use them in
     210             :   // two situations at the moment:
     211             :   //
     212             :   // 1) Functions used in WebIDL Func annotations.
     213             :   // 2) Bindings code or other code called directly from the JS engine.
     214             :   //
     215             :   // Use pretty much anywhere else is almost certainly wrong and should be
     216             :   // replaced with [NeedsCallerType] annotations in bindings.
     217             : 
     218             :   // Check whether the caller is system if you know you're on the main thread.
     219             :   static bool IsSystemCaller(JSContext* aCx);
     220             : 
     221             :   // Check whether the caller is system if you might be on a worker thread.
     222             :   static bool ThreadsafeIsSystemCaller(JSContext* aCx);
     223             : 
     224             :   // In the traditional Gecko architecture, both C++ code and untrusted JS code
     225             :   // needed to rely on the same XPCOM method/getter/setter to get work done.
     226             :   // This required lots of security checks in the various exposed methods, which
     227             :   // in turn created difficulty in determining whether the caller was script
     228             :   // (whose access needed to be checked) and internal C++ platform code (whose
     229             :   // access did not need to be checked). To address this problem, Gecko had a
     230             :   // convention whereby the absence of script on the stack was interpretted as
     231             :   // "System Caller" and always granted unfettered access.
     232             :   //
     233             :   // Unfortunately, this created a bunch of footguns. For example, when the
     234             :   // implementation of a DOM method wanted to perform a privileged
     235             :   // sub-operation, it needed to "hide" the presence of script on the stack in
     236             :   // order for that sub-operation to be allowed. Additionally, if script could
     237             :   // trigger an API entry point to be invoked in some asynchronous way without
     238             :   // script on the stack, it could potentially perform privilege escalation.
     239             :   //
     240             :   // In the modern world, untrusted script should interact with the platform
     241             :   // exclusively over WebIDL APIs, and platform code has a lot more flexibility
     242             :   // in deciding whether or not to use XPCOM. This gives us the flexibility to
     243             :   // do something better.
     244             :   //
     245             :   // Going forward, APIs should be designed such that any security checks that
     246             :   // ask the question "is my caller allowed to do this?" should live in WebIDL
     247             :   // API entry points, with a separate method provided for internal callers
     248             :   // that just want to get the job done.
     249             :   //
     250             :   // To enforce this and catch bugs, nsContentUtils::SubjectPrincipal will crash
     251             :   // if it is invoked without script on the stack. To land that transition, it
     252             :   // was necessary to go through and whitelist a bunch of callers that were
     253             :   // depending on the old behavior. Those callers should be fixed up, and these
     254             :   // methods should not be used by new code without review from bholley or bz.
     255           0 :   static bool     LegacyIsCallerNativeCode() { return !GetCurrentJSContext(); }
     256           0 :   static bool     LegacyIsCallerChromeOrNativeCode() { return LegacyIsCallerNativeCode() || IsCallerChrome(); }
     257             :   static nsIPrincipal* SubjectPrincipalOrSystemIfNativeCaller()
     258             :   {
     259             :     if (!GetCurrentJSContext()) {
     260             :       return GetSystemPrincipal();
     261             :     }
     262             :     return SubjectPrincipal();
     263             :   }
     264             : 
     265             :   static bool LookupBindingMember(JSContext* aCx, nsIContent *aContent,

     275             :   // screen size. If the inputWidth/Height is greater than the available content
     276             :   // size, this will report the available content size. Otherwise, it will

    2718             :   // The order of these entries matters, as we use std::min for total ordering
    2719             :   // of permissions. Private Browsing is considered to be more limiting
    2720             :   // then session scoping
    2721             :   enum class StorageAccess {
    2722             :     // Don't allow access to the storage
    2723             :     eDeny = 0,
    2724             :     // Allow access to the storage, but only if it is secure to do so in a
    2725             :     // private browsing context.
    2726             :     ePrivateBrowsing = 1,
    2727             :     // Allow access to the storage, but only persist it for the current session
    2728             :     eSessionScoped = 2,
    2729             :     // Allow access to the storage
    2730             :     eAllow = 3,
    2731             :   };

    3070             : /*
    3071             :  * In the following helper macros we exploit the fact that the result of a
    3072             :  * series of additions will not be finite if any one of the operands in the
    3073             :  * series is not finite.
    3074             :  */
    3075             : #define NS_ENSURE_FINITE(f, rv)                                               \
    3076             :   if (!mozilla::IsFinite(f)) {                                                \
    3077             :     return (rv);                                                              \
    3078             :   }
    3079             : 
    3080             : #define NS_ENSURE_FINITE2(f1, f2, rv)                                         \
    3081             :   if (!mozilla::IsFinite((f1)+(f2))) {                                        \
    3082             :     return (rv);                                                              \
    3083             :   }
    3084             : 
    3085             : #define NS_ENSURE_FINITE4(f1, f2, f3, f4, rv)                                 \
    3086             :   if (!mozilla::IsFinite((f1)+(f2)+(f3)+(f4))) {                              \
    3087             :     return (rv);                                                              \
    3088             :   }
    3089             :

    3092             :     return (rv);                                                              \

    3099             : 
    3100             : // Deletes a linked list iteratively to avoid blowing up the stack (bug 460444).
    3101             : #define NS_CONTENT_DELETE_LIST_MEMBER(type_, ptr_, member_)                   \
    3102             :   {                                                                           \
    3103             :     type_ *cur = (ptr_)->member_;                                             \
    3104             :     (ptr_)->member_ = nullptr;                                                 \
    3105             :     while (cur) {                                                             \
    3106             :       type_ *next = cur->member_;                                             \
    3107             :       cur->member_ = nullptr;                                                  \
    3108             :       delete cur;                                                             \
    3109             :       cur = next;                                                             \
    3110             :     }                                                                         \
    3111             :   }
